Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Interactions between Holocene Lake Levels and Alluvial Fans in the Western U.S. in Response to Changing Climates
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this project is to develop an integrated record of late Holocene hydrologic change and landscape response in the western U.S. to understand the effects of recent climate changes on landscape processes, thereby providing an analog for what may happen in the future under different climate scenarios. This will be accomplished by integrating late Holocene lake-level records of four different basins with their surrounding alluvial fan records along a 450 km north-south transect in the western Great Basin. Raised shorelines surrounding Pyramid and Winnemucca lakes, Walker Lake, and Owens Lake reflect significant fluctuations in the water balance of the region and form excellent time markers that can be used to establish the timing, spatial distribution, and types of floods on alluvial fans across broad areas. These records will be augmented by additional age dating of shorelines and fans to further understand how each lake basin responded to subtle late Holocene climate fluctuations, both in terms of their water balance and the types and frequencies of floods caused by altered climate regimes.
The broader impacts of this research range from educational activities and broad dissemination of results to geologic hazard assessment. The science of delineating flood hazards on alluvial fans is relatively immature compared to assessing hazards associated with river floods. This project will provide critical information on alluvial fan flooding to practitioners of hazard assessments by documenting the timing, frequency, style, spatial extent, and causes of young alluvial fan activity across large areas. The project will utilize a diverse set of tools including geologic mapping, geomorphology, sedimentology, stratigraphy, geochronology, tephrochronology, remote sensing, and paleoclimate analysis to develop a regional synthesis of hydrologic variability and alluvial fan activity across a broad N-S swath of the western U.S. The interdisciplinary nature of this project lends itself to teaching students a variety of skill sets used by Quaternary geologists and will contribute to the education of two graduate students, as well as undergraduate research assistants involved in the project and about 15-20 other students who will enroll in a course based on this research at University of Nevada, Reno. Results will be presented at two or more professional meetings and published in at least two peer-reviewed journal articles. To reach a broader audience, results will also be used to develop an educational module on the effects of climate change on the landscape that will be featured on the Great Basin Paleoenvironmental Database (GBPED) web site (http://www.dri.edu/gbped). The GBPED is a publicly accessible resource viewable in Google earth that provides abstracts of scientific papers on all aspects of environmental change along with place marks that show where the studies were conducted.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to integrate the late Holocene (0 – 5,000 years ago) lake-level records from Pyramid, Winnemucca, and Walker lakes in western Nevada and Owens Lake in southeastern California with the records of alluvial fan deposition around their margins to arrive at a more complete understanding of climatically-induced hydrologic and landscape responses that have occurred during the last few thousand years. During this time period climate boundary conditions have been relatively stable, which implies that whatever climate extremes have occurred over the last few thousand years are still possible under current and future climate conditions. Therefore, this research provides an important long term context for historical droughts and deluges, and helps address the questions of just how dry or wet can it get under the present climate.

We started by refining the Holocene lake-level histories for each of the study basins by compiling existing lake-level data and generating new ages of key shorelines and related deposits. This was accomplished through radiocarbon and luminescence dating. What we found was that each of these basins has experienced several late Holocene highstands when lake levels far exceeded that which has occurred over the last one hundred years or so. Based on modern discharge records from the rivers that feed these basins, these high lake levels probably rose over many years to decades. Similarly, documented low lake levels reflect extensive drought periods that also likely lasted for decades. The main take home message from these refined lake-level records is that relatively long term and severe climate episodes, both on the wet and dry ends of the climate continuum, are possible in our modern climate system.

Once we knew the ages of different shorelines in each of the basins, we were also able to use this information to figure out when and where alluvial fans were active. This process relied on the simple geologic principle of cross-cutting relations between the shorelines and alluvial fans. For example, if a 1000-year old shoreline truncates an alluvial fan, we know that the fan must be older than 1000 years. If the fan is deposited on top of the shoreline and buries it, then the fan must be younger than 1000 years. We employed detailed (1:5,000 scale) geologic mapping to trace the different-aged horizontal shorelines around each of the basins and delineate how each interacted with alluvial fans along its path. In this way, we were able to document the spatial-temporal distribution of Holocene alluvial fans in each of the study basins.

In general, there is a decrease in the coverage of late Holocene alluvial fans along a south to north transect. In other words, the margins of the lake basins in the north (Pyramid and Winnemucca lakes) are less covered by late Holocene alluvial fans than are the basins to the south along the transect (Walker and Owens lakes). This observation agrees with the general pattern of summer thunderstorm activity, where areas to the south are more frequently impacted by thunderstorms than areas to the north along the transect.

This work also allows us to assess the rainfall conditions that lead to debris flows and alluvial fan deposition and the frequency that those types of storms traverse the region, which is important for understanding this natural hazard. On June 10, 2013 a series of thunderstorms formed in the Winnemucca Lake basin, with the heaviest rainfall amounts approaching 4 – 5 inches for that day. A series of debris flows were initiated in many of the mountain drainage basins surrounding the lake bed and were deposited on alluvial fans that day. Preliminary analysis suggests that this was the most intense alluvial fan-forming event in at least the last 80 years, which points to the relative rarity that alluvial fan deposition occurs in this basin. Ongoing efforts are attempting to refine rainfall intensity thresholds for debris flow/alluvial fan activity, and combined with our new data from this project will contribute significantly to our understanding of the range of possible natural hazards in terms of droughts and damaging precipitation events.
